src package¶

Submodules¶

src.const module¶

src.const.interpolationTime = 15¶

max tolerance in minutes for when data should be interpolated, independent of capture period

src.const.resampleStringForHeatmap = '1D'¶

1 days, how data will be resampled to display in heatmap: examples are “3D”=3 days, “7D”=7 day, “1M”= 1 month

assumes name exists in db

Parameters:
  • cursor – db connection cursor
  • name – name of sensor
Returns:

capture peroid of (sensor)name

(not Empty: Bool, pandas dataframe of result which is anonymized in addition)
src.db.getSensorNamesForHouse(cursor, abbreviation)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • cursor – db cursor
  • abbreviation – abbrevation for house
Returns:

array of all sensors as string
src.db.queryForSensor(name, startD, endD)[source]¶

often used in combination with getDFForQuery:

success, result = getDFForQuery(queryForSensor("name", "2018-12-12 12:12:12", "2019-12-12 12:12:12"))
Parameters:
  • name – name of sensor
  • stardD – startdate as string
  • endD – endDate as string:
Returns:

query string to select all values between startdate and enddate
src.db.read_db_config(filename='program_config.ini', section='mysql_shiftable')[source]¶
Parameters:
  • filename – path to program_config.ini
  • section – where to look for db info in .ini file
Returns:

kwargs for MySQLConnection

Example:

config = read_db_config('program_config.ini', section='mysql_nonshiftable')
connection = MySQLConnection(**config)

src.preprocessing module¶

src.preprocessing.combineDfs(dfs, sensorList, startDate, endDate, freq, freqInt, capPeriods)[source]¶

combine all dataframes into one big one, while merging all columns

Parameters:
  • dfs – list of dataframes we want to merge
  • sensorList – list of sensornames, same order as dfs
  • startDate – global startDate we want to choose
  • endDate – global endDate we want to choose
  • freq – frequency as string that we want in the merged dataframe
  • freqInt – frequency as integer that we want in the merged dataframe
  • capPeriods – list of capture periods, same order and length as sensorList
Returns:

merged dataframe
src.preprocessing.convertWhToW(dfs, sensorList, convToPower, capPeriods)[source]¶

converts energy to power, note that the column names are renamed from *energy to *power, everything inplace

Parameters:
  • dfs – list of dataframes of various sensors
  • sensorList – list of the respective sensorname from dfs, order should correspond to dfs
  • capPeriods – list of capture periods of the sensornames from sensorList, order should be the same
src.preprocessing.getRawData(dfs, filteredSensorListRet, capPeriods, basedir, cip, startDate=None, endDate=None, cursor=None, key=None, filteredSensorListDB=None)[source]¶

We check first if there are raw datafiles available in basedir/cip. If there aren’t any, we load the data from the MySQL db, but only if there is a cursor given. After loading the data from the database we store it in basedir/subdir

Warning

if there is no raw data hdf files present in basedir/cip and no cursor is provided, the function simply returns and nothing happens

Parameters:
  • dfs – we load the dataframes of each sensor into this list
  • filteredSensorListRet – in this list we put the sensornames, the order is the same as in dfs
  • capPeriods – in this list we put the capture periods of tje sensors, the order is the same as in dfs
  • basedir – the rawdata is expected/stored in basedir/cip
  • cip – anonymized name of house
  • startDate – only required when we load the data from the db, not required if there are hdf files present
  • endDate – only required when we load the data form the db, not required if there are hdf files present
  • cursor – the db connection cursor, not required if there are hdf files present
  • key – shortName of house, not required if there are hdf files present
  • filteredSensorListDB – sensors we want to load from db; the actual names are constructed like this: [key+'{0}'.format(i) for i in filteredSensorListDB], not required if there are hdf files present
src.preprocessing.mergeTotalConsumptionC(dfs, filteredSensorList, filteredSensorList_OG, capPeriods)[source]¶

special preprocessing function for house C to merge the two sensors that measure the total consumption

Parameters:
  • dfs – list of dataframes, each dataframe contains values of one sensor
  • filteredSensorList – name of the sensors, order is the same as in dfs
  • filteredSensorList_OG – unmodified version, of filteredSensorList
  • capPeriods – capture periods of all sensors, order is the same as dfs
src.preprocessing.preprocessBoilerPower(df2, key)[source]¶

calculates the average boiler power, because we have timestamps where the boiler is turned off/on often not following the capture period

preprocessing is done as well (set index, interpolation)

Parameters:
  • df2 – dataframe of boiler
  • key – sensorname
Returns:

new dataframe, in a 5 min grid
src.preprocessing.readCapPeriods(capPeriods, filteredSensorList, basedir, subdir)[source]¶

aux function to read the capture periods of the sensors from a hdf file

Parameters:
  • capPeriods – capture periods get stored in here
  • filteredSensorList – list of sensor names, same order as capPeriods will be
  • basedir – file is expected in os.path.join(basedir,os.path.join(subdir,"capPeriods"))+".hdf", key="data")
  • subdir – see description of basedir
src.preprocessing.readDFS(dfs, basedir, subdir, sensorList)[source]¶

reads the raw data into a list of dataframes

Parameters:
  • dfs – we store the hdf files that are read in this list
  • basedir – we expect files to be in os.path.join(basedir,os.path.join(subdir,sensorname))+".hdf", key="data")
  • subdir – see description of param basedir
  • sensorList – this list gets filled with names of the sensors in dfs, the order is the same as in dfs
src.preprocessing.roundDuplicateEliminateInterpolateResample(dfs, sensorList, ignoreList, capPeriods)[source]¶

Warning

maybe resample first?

a lot of preprocessing like: setting index, date rounding, duplicate elimination, interpolation, everything inplace

Parameters:
  • dfs – list of dataframes, where each is a sensor
  • sensorList – list of sensornames, same order as dfs
  • ignoreList – do not touch the sensors mentiones in this list
  • capPeriods – list of all capturePeriods, same order as sensorList (and length)
src.preprocessing.saveCapPeriods(capPeriods, filteredSensorList, basedir, subdir)[source]¶

aux function to save the capture periods of the sensors in a hdf file

Parameters:
  • capPeriods – list of capture periods
  • filteredSensorList – list of sensor names, same order as capPeriods
  • basedir – file is saved in os.path.join(basedir,os.path.join(subdir,"capPeriods"))+".hdf", key="data")
  • subdir – see description of basedir
src.preprocessing.saveDFS(dfs, basedir, subdir)[source]¶

saving raw data from MySQL database

Parameters:
  • dfs – list of dataframes, each dataframe is a sensor
  • basedir – filepath is constructed like this: os.path.join(basedir,os.path.join(subdir,sensorname))+".hdf"
  • subdir – see description of basedir

src.public module¶

src.utils module¶

src.utils.anonymise(df, key)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • df – dataframe that we want to anonymize the columns of
  • key – key for anonymization dictionary
src.utils.countNaN(array_like)[source]¶

used in combination with resampling:

df.resample("3D").apply(countNaN)
Parameters:array_like – usually a partial column of dataframe
Returns:scalar value, namely the percentage of NaN values in array_like
src.utils.generateHeatmap(df, size, pmin, pmax, resampleString, preName)[source]¶

generate a heatplot of the missing data, using the seaborn visualization tool

Parameters:
  • df – dataframe where each column is a sensor, index is a date series
  • size – (width, height) tuple in inches of output image
  • pmin – min percentage where colorscale should begin \(\in [0,1)\)
  • pmax – max percentage where colorscale should end \(\in (0,1]\)
  • resampleString – how much should be summarized in block visually, for example “3D” = 3 days: show percentage of NaN per 3 days
  • preName – image will be saved as preName+"_"+resampleString+".png"
src.utils.mask_knans(df, x)[source]¶

we specify a maximum of consecutive NaN we allow to be interpolated

Example usage:

df["col"] = df["col"].interpolate(method='linear').where(mask_knans(df["col"], int(15*60/300)))
Parameters:
  • df – column of pandas dataframe
  • x – maximum tolerance of NaN values
Returns:

boolean mapping of rows where we should interpolate
src.utils.reportMissingData(df, freq)[source]¶

writes start and end date of missing data to a csv file in the “missingData” directory

Parameters:
  • df – dataframe with multiple sensors as columns
  • freq – frequency as integer that df uses
